results.title: Disappearing world revisited. Ep. 3
results.creator_credit: Kathryn Ferguson and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: This three part series made for the Discovery Channel draws its material from the landmark Disappearing World documentary series produced by Granada Television in the 1970s. With each of over fifty episodes supervised by an anthropologist, the series set out to record the way of life of indigenous peoples around the world whose traditional cultures were under threat. Each episode of “Disappearing world revisited” briefly recaps three of these original stories then provides a short overview of the situation of the tribal peoples today. The three stories revisited in Episode 3 are: 1. “Kataragama”: In Sri Lanka, worshippers of the god Kataragama perform extreme feats of devotion. 2. “The Kirghiz of Afghanistan” Looks at the harsh life of the Kirghiz who live in the Pamir region of Afghanistan on the highest plateau in the world at 15,000 feet between the closed borders of Pakistan, China and Russia. 3. “Embera: The End of the Road”: The traditional life of the river people of Colombia is threatened by a new major highway, and exploitation by traders. Presented by Andy Kershaw.

Presented by Andy Kershaw.

results.title: Disappearing world revisited. Ep. 2
results.creator_credit: Kathryn Ferguson and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: This three part series made for the Discovery Channel draws its material from the landmark Disappearing World documentary series produced by Granada Television in the 1970s. With each of over fifty episodes supervised by an anthropologist, the series set out to record the way of life of indigenous peoples around the world whose traditional cultures were under threat. Each episode of “Disappearing world revisited” briefly recaps three of these original stories then provides a short overview of the situation of these people today. The three tribal peoples revisited in Episode 2 are: 1. Sakkudei: Living deep in the jungles of Sumatra, the Sakkudei are nevertheless forced by the Indonesian government to conform with 20th century society. 2. Dervishes of Kurdistan: Dervish tribesmen living in the mountainous frontier of Iran and Iraq perform feats of self mutilation to prove their devotion to Islam. 3. Masai Women: Focuses on the expectations placed on woman from the Masai tribe from the East African Rift Valley of Kenya once they reach child bearing age. Presented by Andy Kershaw.

results.title: Disappearing world revisited. Ep. 1
results.creator_credit: Kathryn Ferguson and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: This three part series made for the Discovery Channel draws its material from the landmark Disappearing World documentary series produced by Granada Television in the 1970s. With each of over fifty episodes supervised by an anthropologist, the series set out to record the way of life of indigenous peoples around the world whose traditional cultures were under threat. Each episode of “Disappearing world revisited” briefly recaps three of these original stories then provides a short overview of the situation of these people today. The three stories revisited in Episode 1 are: 1. Mehinacu: The Mehinacu Indians in Central Brazil perform ceremonies to appease the tree spirits. 2. The Kawelka: Ongka’s Big Moka: The Kawelka people of the Central Highlands in Papua New Guinea organise a “moka” (a ceremonial exchange of pigs). 3. Hmong: Hill tribe people of Laos, the Hmong are caught up in the Vietnam War and forced to flee their traditional homes. Presented by Andy Kershaw.

results.title: Disappearing world
results.brief_description: This series reveals aspects of tribal life and customs, as well as current threats to the cultural and social identity of indigeneous peoples. Each episode is devoted to a different tribe in Papua New Guinea, Brazil, the Solomon Islands and Africa.

results.title: Disappearing forests
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Antelope Films and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
People have cleared forests for dwellings, firewood and farming. Can human needs in such areas be weighed against the needs of the planet and its survival? Satellite images worldwide show forest fires and forest clearance, revealing the extent of forest destruction. The program explores the impact of this on the Earth and on the native peoples who live in affected regions.

results.title: Disappeared racecourses of north west Victoria
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the 6 works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region.
Ian Fisher was a champion jockey in north west Victoria in the 1930s and ‘40s. In this film he and his brother Trenfield recall the tracks they raced on across this region, most of which have now disappeared. Standing on the site of the old Rainbow racecourse, Ian tells the story of winning the Rainbow Cup in 1937 and remembers the people who “made racing” in that era.

results.title: Disability awareness
results.creator_credit: Louise Welsh Schrank and Stage Fright Geneva, Il
results.brief_description: When you encounter someone who is physically or mentally handicapped how do you react? Pity? Discomfort? Either reaction will influence your ability to communicate. This program is essentially about improving communication and relationships with the disabled. Good guidance (“enabling tips”) is given by a deaf woman, a boy whose wheelchair is an extension of his body, and a girl blind from birth. The benefits of integration (mainstreaming) and ‘coaching’ are explored as we learn about the school lives of a child with Down’s Syndrome, a boy with cerebral palsy and the blind girl. The power and importance of non-judgemental language is also covered.

results.title: Dis-Moi Que Tu M'aimes = Tell Me You Love Me
results.creator_credit: Michel Boisrond, Francis Cosne and Gerard Beytout
results.brief_description:
Bertrand and Richard both work in an advertising agency. Richard is married to sweet and submissive Charlotte, whom he treats harshly. Victoire, Bertrand’s wife is less than impressed by this display of chauvinism. Both couple decide to experiment with temporary separation. The men setup camp at the office and the women share a house.

Credits: Producers, Gerard Beytout, Francis Cosne ; director, Michel Boisrond ; writers, Michel Boisrond, Annette Wademant ; photography, Daniel Gaudry ; music, Claude Bolling.
Cast: Mireille Darc, Daniel Ceccaldi, Marie-Jose Nat, Jean-Pierre Marielle, Jean-Pierre Darras.

results.title: Dirty rotten scoundrels (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Frank Oz, Bernard Williams and Orion Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: In Beaumont-sur-mer on the French Riviera, Lawrence Jamison (Michael Caine), a suave stylish con man who is an expert at extracting jewels from rich, married women must find a way to deal with crass new competition in the person of Freddy Benson (Steve Martin), a small time scam artist who tells tragic tales about his grandma to secure a few francs from almost anyone! Eventually they decide to compete and make a wager that whoever cannot swindle a certain naive soap heiress (Glenne Headly) for $50,000 must leave the French Riviera hunting ground. A remake of the 1964 “Bedtime stories”.
